3.2.3. Solutions with Divalent Cation Chloride Salts.
contrast to the monovalent cation chloride salts, in the CaCl
experiments there is a signiﬁcant shift of the band
in the FTIR spectra to lower and higher
dominant FTIR bands in the 1400 cm
relative intensity and position for the precipitates from
solutions containing Ca and Mg in comparison to those
produced in experiments with NaCl or KCl. Bands in this
region correspond to the carbonate asymmetric stretch,
indicating that in the Ca- and Mg-bearing solutions, diﬀerent
carbonate phases were formed. A broad area with multiple IR
is consistent with the formation of

carbonate. The production of a diﬀerent phase is conﬁrmed in

experiments and only platy crystals are observed with both
. In the experiments with the higher
concentration (equivalent to 1 M ionic strength), the
crystals showed a high degree of porosity and appear to be an
crystal faces and a more rhombohedral morphology were also
observed. EDX spectroscopy of the crystals showed that both
contained Ca, consistent with the identiﬁcation of calcite using
m-resolved Raman spectroscopy of the precipitated crystals
with diﬀerent morphologies. Lowering the CaCl
tration produced very similar crystal morphologies to those
observed in the KCl and NaCl experiment, as well as ﬂat
spectroscopic analysis of the ﬂat crystal showed that they
contained Ca and were later identiﬁed as calcite based on their
Raman spectrum. In contrast, the prismatic crystals were
identiﬁed as zabuyelite. The Raman spectra for the platy
(not shown). Analysis of the Raman spectra show

in the solution. PHREEQC simulations predict the formation
of calcite and magnesite in the experiments.
presence of sulfate also produced only zabuyelite crystals, as

for the 1 MNaCl solution, nucleation in these experiments was
observed to be slower than in the absence of additives. These
crystals also had a morphology similar to the crystals observed
